title: What should I do when I'm bored? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ahhh yes, if anybody has tried to master this question, it's me. Well a definite boredom killer is playing video games. Video games, computer games, mobile games. Basically any game. You can even throw board games and card games and other types of traditional games in there. I think games were created specifically to do away with boredom, obviously. I am a huge fan of all kinds of games. Next, try picking up a good book. Reading can kill hours upon hours upon hours of time. Reading is a very constructive activity that sharpens your imagination and your mind. You will learn so much through books. Read widely and read deeply as high school SAT counselors advise students. Explore new hobbies. There are a plethora of hobbies, many creative ones, that you can pick up and really indulge in. Maybe you would love to learn how to dance, or play an instrument. Or you can take up scrapbooking, jewelry making, flower arranging. Who knows, with practice and talent, you might even turn said hobby into income! In any case, it will expand your world and offer you excitement and stimulation. In constrast to creative hobbies, one can also explore scientific and technical hobbies. Maybe, your city has a local science museum where you can find activities and programs. Try networking and making new friends. Expand your social network and host a party at your home. Parties and social events are always exciting events to look forward to. Get involved. Find organizations in your locality where you can become an active member. Maybe it is a cultural, political, or volunteer organization. You can dedicate your time and energy there. Plus, such involvements look great on a resume, especially if you take on leadership roles. Plan a trip or travel destination. Travelling is always an exciting and enriching experience. You will have some goal to save up for. And planning a dream vacation beforehand with a full itinerary will get you feeling excited and adventurous. Plus, planning ahead means less hassle when it's time to go. These are some of my suggestions as to what one can do when bored. There are, most likely, a million more suggestions, but I obviously cannot list them all in this one post.

Stuck at home dealing with a bad case of the blahs? Before you let your lethargy get the best of you, remember that boredom is a choice, not a sentence. To prove my point, I put together some super easy (and mostly free-of-charge) things you can do when you find yourself overwhelmed with boredom. From styling your bookshelves to DIY facials, here are thirty ways to have fun the next time you're feeling bored.  (Image credit: Anna Spaller) Organize 1. Free up your phone space. What better time than now to clear out all the stuff taking up space on your phone? Use your downtime to score some extra GBs by deleting old photos, apps you don't use, and old messages. 2. Style your bookshelf. Whether you prefer your bookshelves color-coded or stacked gallery-style, organizing your books is a great way to kill time and freshen up your bookshelf. 3. Organize your closet. If you're anything like me — aka dealing with a tiny overstuffed closet — your wardrobe is likely long overdue for a clean out. Now's your chance to finally clear out your closet and hopefully score some extra storage space. 4. Upgrade your bathroom storage situation. Looking for a new place to store an awkward dresser? There are tons of unexpected bathroom furniture pieces that offer ample bathroom storage opportunities — and now's the time to move some stuff around! 5. Clear out your refrigerator. No matter how much of a clean freak you might be, chances are you have at least one expired item sitting in your refrigerator. Take this free time to clear out your fridge and organize your freezer while you're at it, too. 6. Declutter your place. Why stop at your closet or fridge when you can de-clutter your whole stinkin' place? Take this time to downsize your stuff and make a charitable drop-offwhen you're done.  (Image credit: Shay Spaniola) Clean 7. Deep clean your bathroom. Searching for a productive way to kill a good hour? Give your bathroom a good old-fashioned deep cleaning and you won't have to worry about it being dirty when your schedule picks up again. 8. Or your kitchen. Name one thing more satisfying—and fun to look at—than a sparkly clean kitchen? We won't hold our breath. 9. Or your whole friggin' house. Feeling the buzz of your freshly cleaned bathroom or kitchen? Ride the cleaning wave and keep on tidying up (at least until you think of something better to do). 10. Soften a cheap pair of sheets with vinegar. Too tired to deep clean your place but still searching for something productive to do. Throw your cheap pair of spare sheets in the washer with a cup of baking soda and ½ a cup of vinegar and brace yourself for a good night's sleep. 11. Clean your makeup brushes. Got ten minutes and a couple of hair ties? Rid your dirty makeup brushes of oil buildup and bacteria and give them a thorough upside-down cleaning. 12. Pull out your clothes steamer. You can tackle everything from carpet stains to dirty tile grout in just a matter of minutes with your trusty garment steamer (even travel-sized versions will do).  (Image credit: Minette Hand) Create 13. Make a mood board. Turn your boredom into inspiration and fashion a mood board for your bedroom or home office. 14. Make your own woven rug. Foreseeing a weekend at home? Stop by the fabric store on Friday and by Sunday, you'll have a one-of-a-kind hand-woven rug. 15. Dress up your furniture. Feeling bored but ambitious? Pull out your paintbrush and make a fun stencil, and before you know it, you'll have your very own bone-inay-inspired dresser. 16. Dye your stuff. Looking for a fun way to update your bedding? Grab a pack of fabric dye from the store (it's under five bucks) and tie-dye your sheets and pillowcases. 17. Refinish your furniture. Bored but don't have the budget to go shopping for new furniture? Refinish your furniture's battered wooden legs with metallic contact paper for a revamped look. 18. Repurpose old paper bags. Who knew paper grocery bags had so much design potential? From storage bins to plant holders, you can use your down time to upcycle all those paper bags you've been hoarding.  (Image credit: Minette Hand) Decorate 19. Design a gallery wall. What better time than when you're bored to finally fashion a fabulous gallery wall for your living room? 20. Upcycle old candle jars. Before you throw out your depleted candle jars, consider saving them to repurpose the next time you're bored with nothing to do. 21. Rearrange your living room. Searching for a cheap way to update your whole apartment. Rearrange your living room for a fresh new look that's totally free of charge. 22. Forge an entryway. Dreaming of a proper entryway but stuck with a narrow hall instead? Use your free time to forge a mini-foyer for your apartment with a few coat hooks or a diy dowel coat rack. 23. Refresh your kitchen. Update your kitchen on the cheapby simply hanging up some art or removing your cabinet doors for open shelving.  (Image credit: Esteban Cortez) Play 24. Have friends over. Stuck at home broke with nothing to do? Call your friends over and play a party game with stuff around the house. 25. Phone a friend. Don't feel like company? No worries. Now's your chance to Facetime a friend and catch up without having to switch out of your sweatpants. 26. Determine your decor personality. Feeling especially bored but antisocial? Take our online decor personality quizto figure out your decorating style. 27. Exercise. Boredom doesn't have to turn into laziness. Use your free time to jumpstart your fitness goals with a fun in-home workout routine.  (Image credit: Marisa Vitale) Indulge 28. Sign up for some home catalogs. Home catalogs are ripe with decor inspiration. Sign up for a few of the best home decor catalogs now and you'll have them on hand for the time you feel bored. 29. Bake something delicious. What better time than being bored to channel your inner Julia Child? Treat yourself to something simple but delicious that you baked yourself (no worries if you don't want to share with your roomies). 30. Give yourself a DIY facial. Turn your down time into a spa-day with a DIY facial you can make from stuff you probably already have at home. source: 30 (Mostly Free) Things to Do When You’re Bored

Here are a couple of ideas. Each one of them takes some dedication, so you I hope you’re REALLY bored, and not just lazy.  Learn another language: Go unto Duolingo, or attend a community college class. You don’t even have to pay for it, just walk on in and crash the course. You’ll receive no university credit for it, but that’s not why you’re here, right? I’d also recommend getting phrasebooks and finding other people who speak the language fluently. You’ll need the practice. Try your local Starbucks. You hang out there long enough, and you might be surprised by how many languages you end up hearing. Learn to ride a unicycle: This will take about a week to learn, plus ~$130 for a good unicycle. I dunno, though. People are often trying to get rid of the stuff. I mean, who rides unicycles, anyways? Keep on practicing, and soon you’ll have an obnoxious form of transportation for all occasions. Learn how to solve a Rubik’s cube: These things are everywhere. Steal one from your sibling or claim that it was yours at a lost and found somewhere. Find an online video tutorial for solving. Get some scrap paper for writing down and memorizing algorithms. If you’re REALLY bored, you’ll have learned to solve it by the end of the day. Learn some calculus: Despite how intimidating it might sound, the basics of calculus really aren’t all that difficult. So long as you have a good understanding of algebra (trigonometry can help too, but it’s not entirely mandatory to get started with) you’ll do fine. Get your hands on an introductory textbook, find a decent tutor from the aforementioned community college you’re freeloading off of, and give it a go. You’ll also be relying heavily on Desmos graphing calculator and Wolfram|Alpha. Go to a community service event: Be it providing for a homeless shelter, a soup kitchen, a marathon, or a clothes drive, it’s a decent way to spend the afternoon/evening, while receiving community service forms that you can either staple to a job application or an incarceration form to hand to your employer/probation officer. (Is there really a difference when you get down to it? IDK) Plus, you feel smugly morally superior by the time you’re done with it. Learn how to juggle: Juggling’s one of those ridiculously simple things that takes a great deal of practice. I learned how to juggle by using some balled up socks. Whatever you do, don’t use tennis balls. Those just make it extraordinarily frustrating whenever they bounce off of the palm of your hand and roll under the couch. Give it a few days.Juggle Rubik’s cubes while riding a unicycle: I’m not quite sure what you’d be hoping to accomplish with this one, but hey, you SAID you were bored, didn’t you?

When you are bored just think about a few things that don't make sense ...like ;  1. If poison expires, is it more poisonous or is it no longer poisonous?  2. Which letter is silent in the word "Scent," the S or the C?  3. Do twins ever realize that one of them is unplanned?  4. Why is the letter W, in English, called double U? Shouldn't it be called double V?  5. Maybe oxygen is slowly killing you and It just takes 75-100 years to fully work.  6. Every time you clean something, you just make something else dirty.  7. The word "swims" upside-down is still "swims"  8. 100 years ago everyone owned a horse and only the rich had cars. Today everyone has cars and only the rich own horses.  9. If you replace "W" with "T" in "What, Where and When", you get the answer to each of them.  Six great confusions still unresolved  1. At a movie theatre, which arm rest is yours? 2. If people evolve from monkeys, why are monkeys still around? 3. Why is there a 'D' in fridge, but not in refrigerator? 4. Who knew what time it was when the first clock was made? And now sixer .... Vagaries of English Language! Enjoy!!! - Wonder why the word funeral starts with FUN? -Why isn't a Fireman called a Water-man? - How come Lipstick doesn't do what it says? - If money doesn't grow on trees, how come Banks have Branches? - If a Vegetarian eats vegetables, what does a Humanitarian eat? - How do you get off a non-stop Flight? - Why are goods sent by ship called CARGO and those sent by truck SHIPMENT? - Why do we put cups in the dishwasher and the dishes in the Cupboard? - Why do doctors 'practice' medicine? Are they having practice at the cost of the patients? - Why is it called 'Rush Hour' when traffic moves at its slowest then? - How come Noses run and Feet smell? - Why do they call it a TV 'set' when there is only one? - What are you vacating when you go on a vacation? We can never find the answers, can we? So just enjoy the pun and fun of the English language!!

Do you feel “blah" in an area of your life? Maybe it’s your: Career: your job/study doesn’t inspire you anymore, and you wonder if there is something better out there.Relationship: you are feeling numb in your marriage/relationship and wish you could feel deeply in love againHome: you are tired of where you live and long for somewhere with a different energy to it.Now something different have to do……. 1. Channel your seven-year-old self. What would you want to do right now? Color? Paint? Run around outside? Play dress up? Eat with your hands? Play that instrument hiding in the back of your closet that you haven’t touched in years? Just because you’re a grown up doesn’t mean any of this stuff will be less enjoyable than you remember it. Give yourself permission to play.  2. Speaking of little kids, if you have your own or access to any (in a non-creepy way, like they’re your niece or your best friend’s kid, you get the idea) go play with them! They also keep things so simple, and we can really stand to be reminded of this and stop allowing ourselves to get bogged down in boring details.  3. Order a hot dog. While you’re eating it, Google: “What’s in a hot dog?” You decide whether or not you want to finish it.  4. This one is for the ladies: wear your sexiest lingerie under your work clothes. Your “little secret” will leave you feeling anything but boring all day!  5. Play cell phone roulette. You’ll need at least one buddy for this. Scroll through the contacts in your phone, stop on a random one and call the person. Could spark an incredible catch up session. Could be incredibly awkward. Neither are boring.  6. Fill out a pack of Thank-You cards. Give them to random people who probably don’t get thanked too often for doing what they do ever day. Ideas: police officers, librarians, servers, baristas, cab drivers, sanitation workers, teachers, people behind any check out counter, receptionists, your friends, the guy at the falafel stand, etc. 7. Sign up for a class in something you’ve “always wanted to do”, or something that makes you really uncomfortable. Ideas: pole dancing, salsa lessons, cooking, knitting (yup, there are classes for this, too!), karate, boxing, something techy like the workshops they run in stores, learn language you’ve always wanted to speak, etc.   8. Interview your grandparents about their life. You can bet they’ve had some crazy experiences you probably never knew about. 9. Get up on stage at an open mic night whether you’re funny or not (and if you’re not, memorize a few of your favorite jokes and tell those!) 10. Do something for someone else that you wish someone would do for you. We all have a few ideas on this list. I promise you will feel amazing after and anything but bored. 11. Plan a weekend trip or an all-out vacation. This will give you something to look forward to.  12. People watch. Find a bench in a crowded area (centers of transportation like airports, bus stops and train stations are great for this!) and just observe. People are infinitely interesting.  13. Eat something you’ve never eaten before. It totally depends on you 14. Dance. You can get your friends together for a night on the town or just pull up a video on YouTube and bust a move from your own living room. If you’re feeling extra brave, you can even dance in public.  15. Step away from the computer and go get some time with people you care about IRL. (That stands for In Real Life). Facebook stalking doesn’t count as real social interaction. If this is not working then dont worry try to make your own list.

Go for a walk and go to unexplored parts you’ve never bothered to seeGo for a hike, which is like a walk but more destination and sight-focussedRead a book; join the library if you have one nearbyRead a book about something you never looked into before or views thing a different way from how you view themWrite a short story or bookMake dinnerLearn to cookPaint the living roomSing a songGo dancingLearn to dance wellTake up macraméWrite yourself a letter to your older self that you’ll open and read in 10 years.Clean the kitchen and re-organize things in a more sensible wayCollect all the dirty clothes & towels in the house and do laundryRead a book while waiting for the laundry to finishThen iron those items that need it and hang them up in each person’s closet.Don’t tell anyone you were the one who did their laundryGo to the local animal shelter and sign up as a volunteer and walk the dogs every now and again.Foster some of the animals at the shelterTake a sculpting or painting classStart a Neighbourhood Sock Drive and give the local homeless shelter a few dozen pairs of new socks. Socks are a high need item for homeless folks.Learn to read musicLearn to play an instrumentGo visit an old age home and sign up as a volunteer then go spend time with people who really could use the company.Make a list of things you could do to not be bored, then do them all.There are endless ways to keep yourself occupied, many of them are actually useful, some are just plain fun.

A lot of these answers are filled with ideas and similar suggestions if you google this question: read a book, learn a new language, discover a new hobby, etc. And those, of course, are all great suggestions. I’m not knocking them. So hopefully no one takes it that way. As someone who had suffered an unshakable sense of boredom for decades (and this is no exaggeration … thank you, depression, for that one), I found most of these suggestions given just left me feeling empty and still bored. I tried for years to conquer boredom, to no avail. Reading a book? Bored. Play guitar? Bored. Go to a class to learn something (salsa, knitting, etc)? Bored. Took two years of German and private lessons … still bored. Biked for hours … still bored. Went to the gym daily … bored. (I’m a lifelong athlete and runner and running is the one thing that I love…but I was out of running commission for awhile. So while I work out daily … I really only love running and team sports.) Little worked for me except for the following, so I’m suggesting this only if you are suffering from a boredom that seems to stick around, and you have a budget to work with (or are a responsible credit card owner and can pay off monthly statements in exchange for exhilaration and in return you will get some nice travel perks or other points): Buy a scooter. < — Game changer; preferably one you need a motorcycle license for. (They go faster.) Hell, buy a motorcycle instead, if you want. I bought a sweet scooter that went up to 70 mph and that thing made me feel alive every single time I rode it. It cost $2000. Cost of gas for the tank? Between $1–$2, premium gas, to fill my tank and it lasted for at least 50 miles. It was my best purchase ever.Buy a plane ticket to some place you’ve always wanted to go. Find a cheap one and you can easily find cheap accommodations through a number of sites. Sticking yourself into a new culture can shake things up. Seeing new sites can shake things up. Getting lost in a new city is fantastic. Even if you literally get lost.Just pack up and move, if you don’t have some major responsibility tying you down. That’s what I did. I woke up every day hating where I lived (my hometown), feeling empty and completely uninspired. I looked around at my surroundings for years and thought “Why am I in this place?”. So, I decided to apply to grad school in Stockholm, Sweden because I love the city. I applied to one school. Got in. Sold everything. And moved abroad. And while nothing has gone smooth here in any way in the two years I’ve lived here, that feeling of being bored has completely vanished. I still struggle with depression but that perpetual boredom … has lifted.

When I was a kid, I developed this habit of saying “I’m bored.” It became this sort of odd reaction to any moment I wasn’t being physically active. Whether I was in the car, having a meal with my family, on vacation - it really didn’t matter. I said I was “bored.” I remember so vividly this seemingly insignificant, but life-changing moment I was in the car with my parents and brothers when I repeated my favorite repetitive sentence when my dad stopped the car and turned to me and said, “Boredom is a state of mind, not a fact. When you’re bored, you ARE boredom. There’s no such thing as a situation being boring. Saying you’re bored is a sentence about your being, not the situation.” I was 13 at the time. The wisdom hit me like a ton of bricks; for the first time I thought - “what the hell does it even mean to BE bored?” Like anything else in life, an adjective we use to describe a situation usually has NOTHING to do with the situation itself, but how we’re relating to it. Saying “this is boring” or I’m bored” simply means that we’ve decided to relate to a circumstance as boring. It means that we haven’t been able to find a relationship to this circumstance as interesting, fun, or enjoyable. This is going to seem a little harsh, but I don’t intend it as an insult in any way. Sometimes we need a little bit of reality to change the way we’re thinking about something. So - to answer your question of what you should do when you’re bored - realize that boredom is a state of mind, and find a way to relate differently to your circumstance. If you’re bored, you can always… do something that’s not boring! Read a bookThink about something that interests youLearn something you don’t knowDo some work you’ll have to do laterListen to musicCall someone you missThank a friend or family member for something they did for you in the pastBe grateful that you’re alive….. there’s always something TO DO. If you can’t find something to DO when you’re feeling bored, then you need to question whether you have enough interest in life.

Humans are creatures of intellect. Boredom is a creation of your intellect. It’s the revolt of your brain, which craves for knowledge. I can give you a list of activities you could do when bored. That would be giving you a fish. You’d benefit a lot more from learning how to fish though. Think about the activities you’re spending the most time on. When battling boredom, basically you can divide them in two major groups: activities stimulating your intellect, and activities not doing that. The first group contains things like writing, reading, painting, sports, learning, playing an instrument, having engaging and challenging conversations with smart and educated peers, doing creative and productive work on a project. They don’t seem like fun to most people, generally because enjoying those activities requires a level of commitment and a learning curve that most people lack. You need to be familiar with a few general principles and practices, but then you’re free to dive into the endless pools of engagement those activities can provide. The second group includes watching garbage TV and reality shows, playing video games and conversing with shallow-minded individuals or groups. They don’t engage your mind to its full capacities. You gain little or nothing when participating. You grow tired of them quickly, and you try to replace them with other similar activities. The cycle is hard to leave. I know, I’ve been there. The more you engage in stimulating activities, the faster time flies. You might get bored from them occasionally, but that’s because you’re physically tired from doing them for hours in a row without noticing almost the entire day has passed. Once you become a person fully aware and in touch with his intellectual needs, you’ll never be bored again.

What is boredom anyway? You might not realize it, but boredom stimulates a form of anxiety & stress. It evokes an emotional state that creates frustration and feeds procrastination. It’s a desire to be ‘doing something’ or to be ‘entertained’. It’s a desire for sensory stimulation. What it boils down to a lack of focus. If you think about those times when you’re bored it’s usually because you ‘don’t know what to do’. So indecision plays a big part. When we are focused on what’s important to us and what we want to achieve, it’s pretty hard to be bored. So one answer to boredom is to become focused on what you want. Sometimes it’s good to be bored If boredom is a desire for sensory stimulation – then what’s the opposite of that? To be content with no stimulation. In other words, to enjoy stillness. Research has shown that it’s not the ‘boredom’ its-self that causes the frustration, it’s the resistance to doing nothing. Think about it. What would happen if you were to ‘let go’ of the desire to be entertained? You wouldn’t be bored anymore. You would be relaxing! In my experience, it’s often the most obvious, simplistic solutions that are the most powerful in life. So when you’re bored, the easiest way to combat this is to enjoy it. Sounds weird, but think of ‘boredom’ as a form of ‘relaxation’. It’s a break from the constant stimulation that 21st century living provides. The constant TVs, mobile phones, radios, internet, emails, phonecalls… Who knows, maybe ‘boredom’ is actually a good for us? Next time you’re ‘feeling bored’ instead of feeding the frustration by frantically looking for something to do, maybe you can sit back, relax and savor the feeling of having nothing to do. Here’s my 3 step strategy to overcome boredom: 1. Get focused Instead of chasing sensory stimulation at random, focus on what’s really important to you. What would make good use of your time? What could you be doing that would contribute to your major goals in life? Here are a few ideas: Spend some time in quiet contemplation considering what’s important to youStart that creative project you’ve been talking about for the last few weeksBrainstorm: think of some ideas for new innovative products or businesses2. Kill procrastination Boredom is useful in some ways because it give us energy to ‘do things’, so next time you’re bored why not put this good energy to use by ticking off those things that you have been ‘meaning to get done, but have been too busy’. This is a great time to clear your ‘to do’ list. Some ideas: Do some exerciseRead a bookLearn something newCall a friendGet creative (draw, paint, sculpt, create music, write)Spring cleanWash the carRenovate the houseRe-arrange the furnitureWrite your shopping listWater the plantsWalk the dogSort out your mail & emailDe-clutter (clear out that wardrobe)3. Enjoy boredom If none of the above work, then try a different approach. Don’t give in to boredom and instead choose to enjoy it. Contrary to popular belief, we don’t need to be constantly ‘doing things’ in order to be productive. In-fact research has shown that people are more productive when they take periods of rest to recharge. So take some time to relax. You never know you might even like it. Source: Lifehack

It's good to read that you're bored! Because in my way boredom is the great time to do another things than what you do in daily lifestyle! Probably you can pickup any idea you want to do which listed down below! A walk- A walk is the best thing you can done in boredom! You can go for a walk with your pet, your friends, your family. Just walk and talk with them! I remember the days when I was in 10th, when I get bored, I gathered with 2 friends and we go for a walk! My god! We shared too much things in that 20–30min walk! Do it yourself, you feel energised and relaxed! Read- Reading is best way to handle your boredom! Read whatever you want! Read biography, Read novels, Read adventures stories, Read plays! Just read them! Your mind get relaxation after reading! When their were not any one friend with which I can went for walk, I talk to my Father and they gave me books! Books which very small kids read, Books which were used to studied by higher class students, Books of adventurous stories, Books of General knowledge, Books of Jokes! I am sure if you go for your boredom by this technique then prbably you will end up getting relationship with readings, with books! Drawing- Drawing is fun! It literally kills boredom! You can draw anything you want! You don't have to master in drawing for that purpose! Also you can draw jointed eights, it is proven that making jointed eights drawing can refresh your mind! So try it once!you will definitely get reasults! A Ride- Go for a short ride if you have limited time! Go for a long ride if you don't have any time limit! I can't explain you, what's the joy I get when I am riding on my bike! You will also get it if you choose this option! Mostly in rainy season you can go for a ride it feels so soothing to watch the nature, Wet roads, People with umbrella and funny(some) raincoats, Greenery on trees, and the sky! It's just an awsome surprise​ to yourself! I definitely do this, specially in Rainy season! Help Someone- Help your mother in her work!  Help a stranger! Helping someone always better! You will end up getting how they have to work hard to do their thing/to satisfy you! Talking about my self, One day I decided to help my mother! But at other day I get backpain because I was doing that work for first time! At that time I get that how much hardworker my mother was! From that day I constantly heloing her in her work whenever possible! And their are other things also, to do when you are bored! QuoraWatching TVVideo gamesMobile entertainment (Not recommended because we used it out of limit!)And also much more things to do!So what are you waiting for? Just give upvote to this answer and follow me for more answers like this and to whatever you want to kill boredom! Thank you for reading!

Do the things that you thought you would do when you will have time. How many times have you thought “I will clean my room when I have the time”?  Boredom is just a state of having too much time to do anything and in the same time not having the will to do that. There are always things that need to be done. The problem is that they are not always fun, so we choose to be bored instead. I personally have never felt bored. I spend most of the time working and rarely take breaks, that can only destroy my focus and motivation. I assume that we are talking about short periods of boredom, that we have a Continue Reading

I'll share a simple cognitive exercise, without knowing age, background or current circumstance, this should still have some value for you. Know that there is power in awareness of your surroundings and your thoughts. A big part of tapping into that is through focus. Simply focusing on things that are empowering rather than distracting or dis-empowering could be a good tool for you. This starts with developing your awareness, which is sometimes trickier than it appears. It's such a simple concept that it's easy to overlook. But if you work on it, you'll be able to eliminate boredom. The first ste Continue Reading

**** 99 Productive Things To Do When You’re Bored *****  1. Clean your home. 2. Organize files on your phone and computer. 3. Update your resume. 4. Make a new song playlist. 5. Create a weekly meal plan. 6. Set up a life binder. 7. Clean out your inbox. 8. Learn something new on Youtube. 9. Visit a bookstore and buy a motivating book. 10. Print & do some self improvement worksheets. 11. Do a bunch of quick tasks. 12. Study interesting data. 13. Make a wishlist of things you want to do or get. 14. Rearrange your furniture. 15. DIY something pretty for yourself or your home. 16. Watch TED talks and take notes. 1 Continue Reading

Anything. Literally anything! When I was younger I had to babysit my brother all the time. He is twelve years younger than me. I swear, his favourite catch phrase was, “I'm borrreeddd!!” To which I would respond, “Only boring people get bored!” He would laugh and ask what he could possibly do that's any fun. Each and every time I could reel off a list of options and his eyes would boggle at the things I could think of on the spot like that. Now, his excuse was that he was about six years old …. My best advice… Start by being with your boredom. Be bored. Allow yourself to be absolutely totally bored. Feel what that feels like. Let yourself slip into those feelings so, if you were, you don’t let yourself resist them any longer. You want those feelings to be okay with you. Having done that (and only then) are you ready to deal with your boredom. So, next, release your muscles in your stomach, neck and shoulders. Then take a series of slow, deep breaths from your gut and relax as fully as you can as you breathe. Everyone occasionally feels bored - it’s when it becomes chronic that you should reflect on the cause. Constant boredom can be depression in disguise or lead to it. They are not the same, but close cousins. Depression has a great deal of hopelessness attached to it. If you feel the latter, then I would recommend discussing it with your doctor just to check that things are OK. Sometimes we all need a break from “the daily grind”.
